subclusters.subcluster_name: Genetic Programmed Aging and Switch Theories

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Genetic Programmed Aging and Switch Theories
theory_assignments.reasoning: This theory posits a built-in genetic program activating senescence via gene cascades, fitting the theme of genetically programmed aging and genetic switches controlling aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Genetic Programmed Aging and Switch Theories
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes a genetic switch turning off survival pathways post-reproduction, a clear example of programmed genetic control of aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Genetic Programmed Aging and Switch Theories
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on genetically encoded aging programs and evolutionary basis, aligning with genetic programming of aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Genetic Programmed Aging and Switch Theories
theory_assignments.reasoning: Phenoptosis theory views aging as genetically programmed organismal death, fitting programmed genetic aging mechanisms.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Genetic Programmed Aging and Switch Theories
theory_assignments.reasoning: Programmed decline in cellular bioenergetics as a genetic aging clock fits programmed genetic aging mechanisms.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Genetic Programmed Aging and Switch Theories
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes genetic programming of aging and cellular responsiveness decline, fitting genetic programmed aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Genetic Programmed Aging and Switch Theories
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on gerontogenes and genetic regulation of longevity, fitting the genetic programming theme.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Genetic Programmed Aging and Switch Theories
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes a genetic network regulating aging and longevity, fitting genetic programmed aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Genetic Programmed Aging and Switch Theories
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on genetic control of aging via gene activation/deactivation and systemic regulation, fitting genetic programmed aging.
Focuses on telomere shortening and subtelomere repression as a programmed aging mechanism, a distinct telomere-based genetic program.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Environmental Modulation of Genetic Aging Program Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes temperature-dependent genetic regulation of aging via thermosensory neurons, linking environment to genetic aging programs.
Focuses on GH/IGF-I, TOR, and nutrient sensing pathways modulated by protein intake, fitting nutrient-sensing aging mechanisms.
Describes INS/IGF1, AMPK, and mTOR pathways coordinating energy sensing and aging, fitting nutrient-sensing mechanisms.
MDL-1 acts downstream of insulin/IGF-1 signaling to suppress growth and promote longevity, fitting nutrient-sensing pathway modulation.
Intermittent fasting extends lifespan via RHEB-1 and insulin/IGF-like signaling, linking nutrient sensing to longevity.
IGF-1R signaling centrally regulates hypothermia during calorie restriction, linking nutrient sensing and energy homeostasis to aging.
Suppressed GH/IGF-1 signaling promotes longevity and mediates calorie restriction effects, fitting nutrient-sensing modulation.
Caloric restriction modulates IGF-1, mTOR, and insulin signaling pathways to extend lifespan, fitting nutrient-sensing mechanisms.
TOR/Sch9 and Ras/PKA nutrient-sensing pathways regulate longevity via autophagy and stress resistance, fitting nutrient-sensing aging.
Hormonal regulation of aging via insulin/IGF-1 signaling and metabolic syndrome links nutrient sensing to aging.
Pro-aging signaling via TOR/Sch9 and Ras/PKA pathways in yeast, conserved nutrient sensing regulating aging.
Genetic regulation of longevity via sirtuins, insulin/IGF, and TOR pathways, all nutrient-sensing related.
SCH9 deletion triggers longevity program via metabolic reprogramming and ROS reduction, fitting nutrient-sensing pathway modulation.
SIR2 mediates calorie restriction effects on lifespan via NAD-dependent deacetylation, a sirtuin-centered nutrient sensing mechanism.
Conserved nutrient sensing and translational control pathways regulate longevity, fitting nutrient-sensing mechanisms.
Sirtuins link metabolism and aging, mediate calorie restriction benefits, and are NAD+-dependent, fitting sirtuin-mediated CR theories.
Sir2 regulates lifespan via NAD+ metabolism and calorie restriction, fitting sirtuin-mediated CR longevity mechanisms.
Genetic regulation of longevity via IGF1 signaling QTLs, fitting nutrient-sensing pathway modulation.
